recommendations.item_metadata: [{"category":["CDs & Vinyl","Jazz"],"description":["EU-only four CD set containing seven original albums by the Jazz legend. Includes the albums John Coltrane, Blue Train, Soultrane, Lushlife, Ole Coltrane, Coltrane Plays the Blues and Coltrane. Real Gone Jazz."],"title":"John Coltrane Vol 3 -  7 Classic Albums","brand":"John Coltrane Vol3","rank":"114,699 in CDs & Vinyl (","asin":"B00FNBD1IO","imageURLHighRes":["https:\/\/images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com\/images\/I\/51gv07u8YLL.jpg"],"details":{"Audio CD":"(January 1, 2015)","Number of Discs:":"4","Label:":"Real Gone","ASIN:":"B00FNBD1IO"}}]

[{"category":["CDs & Vinyl","Jazz","Avant Garde & Free Jazz"],"description":["No Description Available.
Genre: <\/b>Jazz Music
Media Format: <\/b>Compact Disk
Rating: <\/b>
Release Date: <\/b>4-APR-2000","David Murray's octet has been one of his most successful outlets, emphasizing the tenor saxophonist's deep roots in all jazz traditions and combining ferocious swing with complex contrapuntal charts and explosive improvisation. Murray wrote the arrangements for this tribute and the repertoire touches on several points in John Coltrane<\/a>'s rapid musical evolution. \"Lazy Bird\" (from 1957's Blue Train<\/i><\/a>) has roots in hard bop and \"India\"--from 1961--is an exotic mix of throbbing rhythm, flute, and bass clarinet. Murray bridges time brilliantly in \"Giant Steps\" and also places some special written demands on the band, orchestrating Coltrane's own legendary solo as a backdrop for the soloists. Unlike many saxophonists, Murray has never mimicked the Coltrane sound, opting for the grittier, sonic tradition of Coleman Hawkins<\/a>, Ben Webster<\/a>, and Sonny Rollins<\/a> while constructing his style on post-Coltrane models like Albert Ayler<\/a>, Pharoah Sanders<\/a>, and Archie Shepp<\/a>. That contributes to the distinctiveness of the lyrical \"Naima,\" his rough-hewn tenor beautifully set amidst James Spaulding<\/a>'s flute and D.D. Jackson's shimmering piano. Elsewhere, Murray's booting tenor drives adventurous, leaping phrasing, and he's just as effective on bass clarinet. Trombonist Craig Harris brings suave bluster, matchless diction, and surprising highs to his solos. There's also solid work from the rest of this new edition of the octet, including trumpeters Ravi Best and Rassul Siddik, bassist Jaribu Shahid, and drummer Mark Johnson. While the emphasis is on the best-known tunes, this music has its own strong personality, making it the most fitting kind of tribute to Coltrane. --Stuart Broomer<\/i>"],"title":"Octet Plays Trane","brand":"David Murray","rank":"437,213 in CDs & Vinyl (","asin":"B00004RBZF","imageURLHighRes":["https:\/\/images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com\/images\/I\/513-SCsb78L.jpg"],"details":{"Audio CD":"(April 4, 2000)","Number of Discs:":"1","Label:":"Justin Time Records","ASIN:":"B00004RBZF"}},{"category":["CDs & Vinyl","Jazz","Avant Garde & Free Jazz"],"description":["No Description Available.

Release Date: <\/b>4-APR-2000","David Murray's octet has been one of his most successful outlets, emphasizing the tenor saxophonist's deep roots in all jazz traditions and combining ferocious swing with complex contrapuntal charts and explosive improvisation. Murray wrote the arrangements for this tribute and the repertoire touches on several points in John Coltrane<\/a>'s rapid musical evolution. \"Lazy Bird\" (from 1957's Blue Train<\/i><\/a>) has roots in hard bop and \"India\"--from 1961--is an exotic mix of throbbing rhythm, flute, and bass clarinet. Murray bridges time brilliantly in \"Giant Steps\" and also places some special written demands on the band, orchestrating Coltrane's own legendary solo as a backdrop for the soloists. Unlike many saxophonists, Murray has never mimicked the Coltrane sound, opting for the grittier, sonic tradition of Coleman Hawkins<\/a>, Ben Webster<\/a>, and Sonny Rollins<\/a> while constructing his style on post-Coltrane models like Albert Ayler<\/a>, Pharoah Sanders<\/a>, and Archie Shepp<\/a>. That contributes to the distinctiveness of the lyrical \"Naima,\" his rough-hewn tenor beautifully set amidst James Spaulding<\/a>'s flute and D.D. Jackson's shimmering piano. Elsewhere, Murray's booting tenor drives adventurous, leaping phrasing, and he's just as effective on bass clarinet. Trombonist Craig Harris brings suave bluster, matchless diction, and surprising highs to his solos. There's also solid work from the rest of this new edition of the octet, including trumpeters Ravi Best and Rassul Siddik, bassist Jaribu Shahid, and drummer Mark Johnson. While the emphasis is on the best-known tunes, this music has its own strong personality, making it the most fitting kind of tribute to Coltrane. --Stuart Broomer<\/i>"],"title":"Octet Plays Trane","brand":"David Murray","rank":"437,213 in CDs & Vinyl (","asin":"B00004RBZF","imageURLHighRes":["https:\/\/images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com\/images\/I\/513-SCsb78L.jpg"],"details":{"Audio CD":"(April 4, 2000)","Number of Discs:":"1","Label:":"Justin Time Records","ASIN:":"B00004RBZF"}}]

[{"category":["CDs & Vinyl","Classic Rock","Psychedelic Rock"],"description":["The Black Angels are excited to reveal ''Clear Lake Forest,'' featuring 7 entirely new tracks, hot on the heels of their acclaimed album ''Indigo Meadow'' released last year. Guitarist Christian Bland invites listeners to accompany the band on a sonic odyssey: ''After roaming through the 'Indigo Meadow,' the time has come to journey to the 'Clear Lake Forest,' where 7 tales of diamonds, executioners, and other strange occurrences await underneath the crystal waves lapping in the lake.''","''[E]qual parts visceral and sweeping, it's perfect for shindigs in the desert or as the soundtrack to your mescaline-fueled escape from heartache.'' -- --Consequence of Sound"],"title":"Clear Lake Forest EP","brand":"The Black Angels","rank":"35,453 in CDs & Vinyl (","asin":"B00KM8GV0I","imageURLHighRes":["https:\/\/images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com\/images\/I\/31BjmEHvdzL.jpg"],"details":{"Audio CD":"(July 22, 2014)","Original Release Date:":"July 22, 2014","Number of Discs:":"1","Label:":"BLUE HORIZON","ASIN:":"B00KM8GV0I"}}]

[{"category":["CDs & Vinyl","Jazz","Avant Garde & Free Jazz"],"description":["2009 release from the Jazz vocalist. Recorded live at Lincoln Center, the premier vocalist of his generation salutes and re-interprets one of the greatest Jazz albums of all time: John Coltrane And Johnny Hartman. This is the album Elling fans have been waiting for! This live performance is a stunning spectrum of music, Both vocal and instrumental. Kurt Elling is the preeminent male Jazz singer today. He has earned eight Grammy nominations, the top spot placement in the Down Beat critics' and Jazz Times reader's polls, four Jazz Journalists Association wins for Best Male Vocalist and the Prix Billie Holiday from the Academe Du Jazz in Paris."],"title":"Dedicated to You: Kurt Elling Sings the Music of Coltrane & Hartman","brand":"Kurt Elling","rank":"50,231 in CDs & Vinyl (","asin":"B00280NYVM","imageURLHighRes":["https:\/\/images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com\/images\/I\/411LQoZmWbL.jpg"],"details":{"Audio CD":"(June 23, 2009)","Number of Discs:":"1","Label:":"Concord Jazz","ASIN:":"B00280NYVM"}}]
